headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Georgia's Race Could Provide Blueprint; Why People Fear Change; Taylor Swift Claims Top 10 Spots on Billboard. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: In Georgia, Republican Governor Brian Kemp is leading his bid for re-election against Democrat Stacey Abrams. Kemp famously did not have the support of former President Trump in his primary. Trump predicted he would go down in flames at the ballot box. Today he will be campaigning with former Vice President Mike Pence, however.I sat down with Kemp to talk about this all-important midterm election, how he sees Trump's role in all of this, and the impact of the other Republican in his state, Herschel Walker, on the ticket. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You come to vote with us this afternoon?COLLINS (voice over): With one week to go before the midterm elections, more than 1.6 million voters in Georgia have already cast their ballots. COLLINS (on camera): It's surpassed the level of 2018. It's almost at a presidential election level. GOV. BRIAN KEMP (R-GA): It's incredible. COLLINS (voice over): Georgia residents turning out in droves in the first election since Governor Brian Kemp signed a new voting bill into law adding restrictions to absentee voting while expanding early voting in most counties.

utterances.speaker: KEMP
utterances.sentences: For them to call it suppressive, the numbers just don't - don't play that fact out.STACEY ABRAMS (D), GEORGIA GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: We have an opportunity --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The bill earned him fierce criticism from Democrats in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: ABRAMS
utterances.sentences: The voter suppression is alive and well in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And inside the White House.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: This makes Jim Crow looks like Jim Eagle.

utterances.speaker: KEMP
utterances.sentences: We had a record vote in the primary and we're seeing it right now in the general election.

utterances.speaker: KEMP
utterances.sentences: I think people are going to make that clear choice as to who they're going to vote for, not just in the U.S. Senate race, but all the way up and down the ballot.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Pressed on whether he views Walker's stance as hypocritical, Kemp sidestepped the matter.

utterances.speaker: KEMP
utterances.sentences: I would just tell you to talk to Herschel Walker about his policies on abortion. I am saying focused on my race and what I can control in trying to help them fight through Joe Biden's inflation.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The Republican governor has instead centered his race on the number one issue he hears from voters, inflation.

utterances.speaker: KEMPS
utterances.sentences: Eggs up 30 percent. Milk, chicken up 15 percent, 17 percent. Gas prices, because of bad domestic energy policy, that's the number one issue. Sixty percent of Americans right now are living paycheck to paycheck.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: As Kemp crisscrosses the state with an economic-driven message, there is a noticeable absence on the campaign trail.COLLINS (on camera): The former president has not been in Georgia in a few months. Why do you think that is?

utterances.speaker: KEMP
utterances.sentences: I don't know. You'd have to ask him that question.Look, I'm focused on getting our vote out. COLLINS (voice over): Despite former President Trump's best efforts, Kemp prevailed in the primary earlier this year and easily defeated his Trump-backed opponent.

utterances.speaker: KEMP
utterances.sentences: And I'm not campaigning on what his record was. You know, I'm campaigning on what I've done in this state.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Kemp's victory revealing the limits of Trump's grip on the party and his efforts to unseated those who refuse to join his fight to overturn the 2020 election. KEMPletting people know what we're for, what our record is. Even when you disagree with people, if you stand for something, they have great appreciation for that.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Kemp unsuccessfully fought a subpoena to appear before a special grand jury in Atlanta investigating Trump's attempts to undermine the election and now must testify once his election is over.

utterances.speaker: KEMP
utterances.sentences: I'll tell them the truth and I'll tell them that I followed the laws and the constitution of this state.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Of course, he and Abrams met again on Sunday night in a debate. They were talking about these early record turnout numbers that they're seeing in Georgia. She said that she believes that people are voting in spite of that election bill that he signed into law, not because of it.And I think one part that's notable is, Gabriel Sterling -

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Who, of course, is a top official in the secretary of state's office, who became so notable during Trump's efforts to undermine and overturn the results -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He said it was - on CNN the other day - voter suppression is just as much a lie as voter fraud. So you're seeing this split between the Republicans and Democrats (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, you are. And, I mean, Gabe Sterling, as we were talking about in the break, is someone who came out and warned against what all of this violent rhetoric and election denial would do. It would mean people would die, right?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And so he said this years ago.The question now is, when you look at all the heat that Kemp and the rest took from SB-202, that bill, what's missed a lot in the conversation is that it -- there are restrictions but it did expand -- extend early voting by weeks. And that's what we're seeing play out right now, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think it's hard to say that there isn't an effort for voter suppression, especially when you look at people who have traditionally been sort of pushed out of the - of the process. HARLOW

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Who -- and the access that they have and people trying to cut out on, you know, souls to the polls and all those kinds of things. So I think it's really tough. You - it depends on what you're looking at, what data you're looking at and -- look, I think it - I think rather than trying to restrict people here and there, I think we should be opening up the voting process as -- it should be as easy to vote as possible.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: As it is to get a cup of coffee.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: People should be allowed to vote.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And to Don's point, I mean, isn't this what Stacey Abrams is saying, Kaitlan, that you don't know who is polling, who is getting access, right?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You can't always tell when there's voter suppression.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's been her argument that she's making. Obviously that was a point of contention between of two of them.I will say one thing, and it's sad that this stands out, but it did stand out in the debate as I watched on Sunday. When both candidates were asked if they would accept the results of the election, no matter what they are, they both said yes that they would.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, amen. I can't believe we have to celebrate that, but, amen.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's interesting because a lot of his things were like, well, you have to ask the other guy. He's - he is on message, but a lot of it is a dodge.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The Trump stuff.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.Obviously, don't forget, one week from tonight CNN's special coverage of the midterm elections will be underway. We begin at 4:00 p.m. in the afternoon, but Don, Poppy, and I will be going all night long to bring you the results.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No pressure. No pressure.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This is our new life, folks, buckle up.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This is our (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No question.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Did you like sleep, because you're not going to get any more of it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Two hours last night, maybe three.Straight ahead, four Michigan State football players now suspended -- look at this video -- for starting a brawl after losing. Why one coach says their punishment won't stop there.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What did happen to them?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Plus, the new record shattered by Taylor Swift.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: With my help.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You should really stay on top of this (ph).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I just want to talk about football, guys

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know. It's going to be so good.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We're on TV. We have to remember that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks for saving me.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I forgot to read my line about Taylor Swift. Thanks for saving me, buddy.As you can tell, it is a big day here at CNN. We've got a new show. We've got a new set. We've got a new, amazing team. You can't see them, but these folks have been working for weeks, weekends, everything. So, thank you to the team.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What? We put all this together ourselves.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Don. No. Stop.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's been Don (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, no, no, no. No, no, no, no.For some of you used to watching at this time, you've got many new faces, but change is hard, and it doesn't seem like it should be that difficult for us to wake up at 2:00 a.m. Yes, it does.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I have been doing this for decades. Not 2Our chief medical correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta joins us with a - did you -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: With his own brain!

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But did you steal this? I heard you (INAUDIBLE) this.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Can I touch a brain? Is that, no? Is that forboden (ph)?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Is that a carry-on do you have to check that in your luggage?DR. SANJAY GUPTA, CNN CHIEF MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: I carried it on, actually. I get some strange looks, yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Where did you get the - can you tell the viewers where you actually got the brain?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I got this brain from the medical school.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: It is used to teach medical students. But now it's going to teach you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: But -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So you say we're hard wired to resist change?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, this is - this is interesting. We like to think of ourselves as these nimble, flexible creatures. But, in fact, we really don't like change.And you can take it a step further. We often see change as a threat. At least that's the way the brain sort of perceives change, as a threat. The emotional centers of our brain tend to get activated. So - so let me just show you here, if we can see this. The brain, these are the frontal lobes here. This is where all your judgment stuff happens. But back here is the emotional center of your brain. And that is typically where new change is first processed.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: And it's not comfortable when you have change. It leads to all sorts of things. You feel a loss of control, Uncertainty is the big one.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: If you don't feel certainty about things, it changes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK, so, listen, I'm going to be - I'm weird, as you know.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You've known me for a long time.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Awe.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Look inside your brain.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I like change. I -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Actually, I'm excited about this. You know, it's a little off- putting. I've got two hours' sleep or whatever. But I kind of like change.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Some people are certainly better at it than others.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Is that weird?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: No, I think that you can -- you can practice becoming better at change. And there's - and there's formulas and strategies to do that. So, as a - as a sort of inherent thing, even kids when - you know, kids like change. Kids are always experiencing new things. But adults often don't experience new things. When's the last time you experienced something for the first time? Doesn't happen very often.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: For you guys, it did, because of the show.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, this morning.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This morning aside, but, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But it' funny because it is something we've all gone through. I mean two of us have moved. We've all started new jobs.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Don has completely flipped his schedule. One thing I do wonder if, when you were looking at this, how does age play a factor in whether or not you're --

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Why are you asking that, Kaitlan?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You're better at change?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are we -- are we calling Don "older"?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, what? Was it -- leave me out this.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I can't believe that you said that you were in eighth grade when he started at CNN.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's true.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: And they put that in the ad. They put that in the promo (ph).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: When we started at CNN, she was in eighth grade.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We were literally just doing the math in our head as we were sitting there having coffee.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Well, interesting you asked that question -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Journalist doing math, but, go on. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Because, yes, younger people do tend to be better at accepting change, except for Don. Don, who's older and still does change well.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: But there's a part of your brain, again I'll just show you this quickly, a little bit in front of the emotional center of the brain which tends to deteriorate or slowly wither away over time. That's a part of the brain that's actually better as accepting change. Sort of incorporating changes into your life. We become more fixed in our ways as we get older.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hey, real quickly, though, we can - what can we do? Like, are there things that we can do that will help us do - do change better? I know that's not great grammar.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, asking for a friend.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Part of it is - is - is really understanding that you - you want to do this and actually incorporating new things into your life. That's - that's one of the big things. There's a famous formula by this guy, Glisher (ph), it comes from the'60s. And I wrote it down for you guys. You can take a look. But basically trying to figure out what's - that's not exactly what I thought it was going to be but the -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That looks simple.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: The - but basically it's the idea of what -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's 6

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: It's too early in the morning for that (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Gosh. What the hell is that?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: This -- how dissatisfied you are with the current situation, what your vision is for how that situation could be different, and what are the steps of action to make that change happen? That's what you really got to sort of figure out.But it can be simple.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I'll give you a quick example. Instead - if you're right- handed, all day today, try drinking your coffee with your left hand. Do something different.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So - so my -- my daughter, as we all know, I missed rehearsal last week because my daughter broke her right arm and she's a righty. So, I didn't bug you about this one. Sanjay gets all my other child health questions. But -- so she's doing everything with her left hand now, including trick-or-treating.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And one of our friends said, she's so resilient. And I was like, I need to be more like my six-year-old, right?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: And it - well, I Hope she does fine.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She'll be fine.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: But if we can incorporate some change into our lives on a regular basis.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Get out of your set patterns. Whatever it may be. Take up a hobby. Do something that's different. That's how you get your brain to - to accept change.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And alcohol helps.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.Thanks, Doc.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE). That's the easy thing, have a couple drinks and you'll -- you're good. Ah, who cares?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Not like you're getting up as early as we are. Some day -

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: What's your excuse?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We're going to need that advice more than ever, so -

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I'm going to leave this right here, guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you, Sanjay.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Please leave the brain with us.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks for visiting us on set on our first day.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: We'll see you guys.Of course.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, who is that again?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm kidding. That is Taylor Swift, shatters records with her latest album "Midnight." You just heard "Anti-hero" topping last week's billboard hot 100 chart. But it's not her only accomplishment with this album.Data's here, you know who Data is, right, our senior data reporter Harry Enten has all the details. Good morning. And he cleaned up. You got a haircut.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Look at - look at - look. LEMON

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He got a sweater.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I got a sweater on.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Sweater weather.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I'm taking after you, Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Sweater weather.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Sweater weather.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm doing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.So, what's the deal with this?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: What's the deal with it? I should be clear, I don't think I've ever listened to any of these songs.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right (ph).

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: And if it weren't for this morning show, I'd have no idea who Taylor Swift would actually be.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Join the club.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: No, I'm kidding a little bit.But, all right, let's talk - let's walk over here and let's get an idea of why the heck we're doing this Taylor Swift segment. And I think this first slide will give you an indication. So, on the billboard top 10 on the hot 100 list, this is the first time - the first time one artist has every single song. Drake actually had nine of the ten once before, but this is the first time one artist had every single song. But that is not the only record that this -- that we've seen this time around. Taylor Swift, look at this, billboard top 10 on the hot 100. The first time women are all ten top slots.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Harry.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Harry.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm going to let you finish. ENTEN

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm joking.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I know it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Everybody knows. Does anybody know that reference? You don't remember that? I'm just kidding.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to let you finish. I'm going to let you finish.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Everyone knows the reference.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Everyone knows it. Go on, Harry. I'm just having a little fun with you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Enten.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Enten, or data, as - as Don -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Data.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Data, as Don has named you. Our buddy is in Taylor's video "Anti-hero." Our buddy comedian Mike Berbiglia (ph). And he was shocked when he saw her talking about why on the "Late Show."

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Really? Well -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really. Do you not know this?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: No, I -- look, I hang out with Mike down at the comedy show (ph).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's a night show, yes.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, "The Tonight Show." Whatever show it was. I'm not surprised that Mike was in this because if there's one thing that I know will interrupt Don - that would wrap us in a conversation it would be somebody else who he wants to talk to instead of me, especially from (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: See, I'll let you finish. I let you finish. HARLOW

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He also talked about, though, how when he - when Taylor Swift texted him he thought maybe he was being catfished. He didn't know that she was actually texting him.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He thought it was someone messing with him.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They're playing music to get us to commercial.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.Harry Enten, thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: See you guys later.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Harry. You look great.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We'll see you. Have a great day, Harry.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Data -- Data.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Harry got all cleaned up. Wow.So, listen, I've got to - you've got to look at this. Look at your screens right now. We are watching live pictures out of the Kennedy Space Center. That's where NASA is about to launch the world's largest rocket in a classified mission.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Not so classified, I guess.
